Award.AwardTitle: Biosensing of non-coding RNAs using nucleic acid-based technology

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award by the Biosensing program supports the development of novel types of flexible and programmable nucleic acid based sensors in order to specifically detect many important RNAs at the sub-micro scale. By amplifying complementary RNA (cRNA), a non-biological derivative of the target, contamination is avoided and high specificity and sensitivity are achieved. The cRNA is connected to a receptor and an enhancer by Watson-Crick nucleotide base pairing to allow maximum flexibility in target selection. To boost sensitivity of RNA detection, the investigators will use DNA linked gold nanoparticles and RNA aptamer networks as enhancers. The PIs will build a robust microfluidic system that incorporates acoustic sensors for wireless detection and differentiation of RNAs.

Recent developments in molecular biology have revealed that RNAs not only transfer genetic information from DNA to protein making machinery, but also act to regulate other vital processes in higher organisms. The tools the PI and his team will develop will allow investigators to selectively detect a wide range of these microRNAs in applications ranging from basic discovery sciences, to environmental engineering, and medicine. The PI will integrate research into undergraduate and graduate education, and work with K-12 teachers recruited from the surrounding community. The project will provide excellent opportunities for interdisciplinary education and training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last several decades, nucleic acids (DNA and RNA) have been found to carry out a variety of regulatory functions within cellular organisms. These discoveries, and very fast inexpensive methods for sequencing nucleic acids, have generated an interest in DNA and RNA as nanomaterials. Many very innovative and discrete DNA nanostructures have been constructed. Because RNA is susceptible to degradation by ribonucleases (RNases) and some metal ions, only a few laboratories dare to use RNA molecules for constructing nanostructures.

Our work produced two novel species of RNAs. One of them we call complementary RNA or, in short, cRNA. The cRNA  is a complement of the target molecule and can be readily synthesized using isothermic amplification method. When a reaction mixture contains modified nucleotides, RNase-resistant cRNAs are produced. We used them to construct a user-friendly colorimetric biosensor for detecting cellular RNAs (Fig. 1).  This biosensor is composed of two single-stranded DNAs that are partially complementary to the cRNA molecule and are attached covalently to 15 nm gold nanoparticles. Binding of a cRNA molecule to two DNA-derivatized gold nanoparticles triggers a red-to-blue color change attributed to the surface plasmon resonance.   Our experiments demonstrated that 10-17M concentrations of cRNAs could be detected. The cRNA-based sensor is able to detect tmRNAs present in a single actively dividing Escherichia coli cell.

To simplify detection of bacterial cells, we designed and synthesized networks composed of RNA aptamers, small oligonucleotides derived by an in vitro selection process called SELEX.  In our detection strategy, we use three to five bacteria-specific aptamers (denoted as PR in Fig. 2) and incorporated them into a detection network (denoted as DN in Fig. 2). Such a network acts like a “molecular octopus” and binds simultaneously to targeted molecules on the surface of bacterial membranes. The interaction between networked aptamers is extremely strong because it is driven by avidity rather than affinity. To visualize pathogen detection, we developed a separate fluorescent network (denoted as GF in Fig. 2) that binds 3,5-difluoro-4-hydroxybenzylidene imidazoline (DFHBI). Upon binding of DFHBI, the FN network emits bright green fluorescence which is intensive enough to be observed by the naked eye under visible blue light as provided by “Dark Reader”, an inexpensive ($400) hand-held lamp.  Moreover, we equipped both DN and FN networks with several copies of a cross-linking module  (denoted as XL in Fig. 2) that can bind to itself. Interactions between XL aptamers stimulate the binding of the FN network to the DN network. The simplest way to detect pathogens on the surface of the infected object is to spray this object first with the solution containing DN networks and then  with the solution containing FN networks. After washing off unbound DN:FN complexes, pathogens can be observed with the naked eye under the Dark Reader lamp.

As RNA is readily degraded by ubiquitous RNases and some metal ions, manufacturing RNA-based nanostructures is very challenging.  RNase contamination leads to failed experiments, and tracing its source is a time-consuming and costly endeavor. To facilitate working with RNA molecules, we produced an aptamer-based microfluidic sensor.  In our assay, we observe a gradual decrease in fluorescence of  the DFHBI:aptamer complexes as they are degraded by RNases. Our microfluidic sensor is likely to stimulate development  RNA-based nanotechnology because it is able to detect minute amounts of RNA degrading agents in a 1 nanoliter sample.
